oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Board of Trade application for shipping permit from St. Cecilia Academy

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Economic aspects; Permits; Nashville (Tenn.); Shipping; St. Cecilia Academy (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: To the Hon Board of Trade for Nashville Tennessee The Sisters of St. Cicilias’ Academy desire permission to import from the City of Cincinnati or Louisville Coal for the use of their school to the amount of three thousand bushels. Sr. Columbia Dittoe
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-page handwritten request from St. Cecilia Academy for permission from the Board of Trade to import coal from Cincinnati or Louisville for use in their school.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dittoe, Sister Columbia
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four Catholic Dominican sisters from Somerset, Ohio, founded St. Cecilia as a female school in 1860, and the first class graduated in 1862. Students from both Tennessee and other states displayed divided loyalties during the Civil War. The fall of the city in 1862 brought federal sentinels to the gates of the institution for the rest of the war. The guards proved a benefit to the academy, allowing it to remain open for the duration of the conflict.
